source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
evidence_span: Oxide thickness measurements were made in hot cells on metallographic cross sections of a number of different fuel rods.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
evidence_span: The oxide thickness measurements obtained by metallography were used to verify the oxide thickness measurements made at poolside with the eddy current (E.C.) probe.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
evidence_span: Figure 10 indicates that good agreement was obtained between the poolside and hot cell measurements.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
evidence_span: It may be noted that the poolside measurements more frequently overestimate the oxide layer thickness than underestimate the thickness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk4
evidence_span: The poolside measurements in general, therefore, produce oxide thickness values that may be higher than the true oxide layer thickness.

evidence_span: the MATPRO corrosion model has a correct temperature dependence

evidence_span: the corrosion parameter as determined by the MATPRO correlation, increases with increasing burnup (or fluence) in a manner that is identical for the cladding types

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk5
evidence_span: Cladding Type 9 has reached a near constant value at $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , whereas Type 1 does not reach a constant value before about $6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk5
evidence_span: Cladding Type 9 has reached a near constant value at $2 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ , whereas Type 1 does not reach a constant value before about $6 0 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk5
evidence_span: the optimum value of SOCAP for good corrosion behavior appears to be around $2 \times 1 0 ^ { - 2 1 } \mathrm { m } ^ { 3 }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk5
evidence_span: the corrosion performance of Zircaloy-4 cladding is improved by longer and/ or higher temperature anneals in the alpha range after the material has been beta quenched

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: The in-reactor corrosion susceptibility of Zircaloy-4 fuel rod cladding is dependent on the thermo-mechanical treatment received by the cladding after beta quenching. Longer annealing times and higher annealing temperatures in the alpha range lead in general to better corrosion performance.
process_step: thermo-mechanical treatment after beta quenching; annealing in alpha range

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: The visual appearance of Zircaloy-4 clad PWR fuel rods changes from a uniform black oxide layer to a mottled black-and-white oxide between 10 and 15 μm thickness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: At 20 μm thickness the oxide layer has a uniform white or tan appearance.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: The oxide layer formed on Zircaloy-4 PWR fuel rods may start delaminating at a thickness of 60 to 80 μm and part of the oxide may spall off.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: The corrosion parameter, incorporated in a modified MATPRO corrosion model, provides a measure of the corrosion susceptibility of Zircaloy-4 cladding of a given chemical composition and produced by a given thermo-mechanical treatment.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: The corrosion parameter shows good correlation with the second-order cumulative annealing parameter (SOCAP) defined by Gros and Wadier [5]. This parameter is related to the size of intermetallic precipitates in Zircaloy-4.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: The minima in oxide thickness at spacer grid positions and at positions downstream from the grids are due to lower cladding surface temperatures resulting from more turbulent coolant flow within the grids and at the exit of the grids.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk6
evidence_span: With sufficient detail in the thermal-hydraulics calculations and an accurate calculation of the metal-oxide interface temperature at every point along the fuel rod, it is in principle possible to predict the whole oxide profile with only a single corrosion parameter.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: Their Figure 8 indicates for specimens tested up to 64 days in 400‰ steam a large drop in weight gain for material with a rather low annealing parameter and no difference in corrosion behavior for materials with a higher annealing parameter.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: At longer testing times up to 150 days the drop-off seems to shift to higher annealing parameters.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: the in-reactor test data typically ranges from 1 to 4 years.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: The A parameter in the MATPRO equations is independent of fast neutron flux.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: The oxide thermal conductivity used in our model is 1.73 W/m/K.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: The data in Fig. 9 show oxide layer thicknesses up to 50 μm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_046_chunk7
evidence_span: we have indeed observed oxide spalling at thicknesses exceeding 70 μm.
